channel.title: Help with mute command
channel.description: okay i added a mute and unmute command. the mute command works. it mutes the char and he can't yell or speak. but if he logs the mute is not saved into the char file. how might i get to save into the char file? do i have to declair it or something?

item.title: Help with mute command
item.dc:creator: @God11 God11
item.description:
@God11 wrote:

how would i do that?[br][br][size=1]Posted on: August 06, 2009, 06:22:35 pm[/size][hr]how would i configure the filewriter to save the mute varialbes? is there a tut on this ? cause i searched and couldnt find one

Read full topic

item.title: Help with mute command
item.dc:creator: @Lord_of_fallen_Angel Lord of fallen Angels
item.description:
@Lord_of_fallen_Angel wrote:

You have to configure the FileWriter to save the Mute variables, so when the Chatacter logs in, the FileManager will then load the Variables in the Chatacter Save.

Read full topic

item.title: Help with mute command
item.dc:creator: @God11 God11
item.description:
@God11 wrote:

okay idk if i declaired it right because i added that 2nd code into player handler but i still get these 2 errors

client.java:12296: incompatible types found : boolean required: int p.muted = true; ^ client.java:12297: cannot find symbol symbol : method writeLog(java.lang.String,java.lang.String) location: class client writeLog(p.playerName, "mutes"); ^
whats that mean? did i declair it right?
Edited: i fixed the first error about the p.muted== true thing but idk what to do for the writelog one[br][br][size=1]Posted on: August 06, 2009, 02:09:18 pm[/size][hr]anyone kno how to fix that second error?

Read full topic

item.title: Help with mute command
item.dc:creator: @Tree_Climber Tree_Climber
item.description:
@Tree_Climber wrote:

[quote=“Hextion, post:5, topic:293269”][quote author=Sir Jay link=topic=388073.msg2901691#msg2901691 date=1249564317]

Make it write it into a muted.dat file.

Idiot.

You need to use something called the BufferWriter, this writes a certain object into a file.

Thats what i was trying to say you prick.
[/quote]
Writing it into a .dat file wouldn’t work.[/quote]
Why is that exactly? You could store it as a .dat.
I personally would store it in my players row in my SQL database.
Also, your writeLog method is extremely inefficient, it creates a new BufferedWriter instance every time you go to write a log, instead of just leaving one open to continue writing to the file.

Read full topic

item.title: Help with mute command
item.dc:creator: @Hextion Hextion
item.description:
@Hextion wrote:

Sir Jay:

Make it write it into a muted.dat file.

Idiot.

You need to use something called the BufferWriter, this writes a certain object into a file.

Writelog method is basically the same;

[code] if (command.startsWith(“mute”) && playerRights > 0) {
try {
String otherPName = command.substring(5);
int otherPIndex = PlayerHandler.getPlayerID(otherPName);

                if (otherPIndex != -1) {
                    client p = (client) server.playerHandler.players[otherPIndex];

                    p.muted = true;
		writeLog(p.playerName, "mutes");
		sM("You have muted "+p.playerName+"!");
                } else { 
                   sM("The name doesnt exist."); 
                }
            } catch (Exception e) { 
                sM("Try entering a name you want to mute..");
            }
        }[/code]

The above command is the Mute command, it will track the user you want to mute and use the Writelog void to send to the correct folder and file. If the play is not found it will print;

The name doesnt exist.

You may need to declare

public boolean muted;

in your playerHandler.java

If you haven’t got a Writelog method, then declare it;

[code] public void writeLog(String data, String file) {
BufferedWriter bw = null;

	try {
		bw = new BufferedWriter(new FileWriter("config//" + file + ".txt",
				true));
		bw.write(data);
		bw.newLine();
		bw.flush();
	} catch (IOException ioe) {
		ioe.printStackTrace();
	} finally {
		if (bw != null)
			try {
				bw.close();
			} catch (IOException ioe2) {
				System.out.println("Error writing system log.");
				ioe2.printStackTrace();
			}
	}
}[/code]

Notice the above void has got the BufferWriter method. This will locate the correct folder you would like to send the object(s) to, you can change the directory of the folder by using this line and editing it;

			bw = new BufferedWriter(new FileWriter("config//" + file + ".txt", true));

If the folder is not located, it will display;

Error writing system log.
in your command prompt.

Read full topic
